thread.title: Let's put Bret Bielema vs. Cam Robinson to rest
thread.title_full: Let's put Bret Bielema vs. Cam Robinson to rest

author: Kevin Scarbinsky | kscarbinsky@al.com
title: Let's put Bret Bielema vs. Cam Robinson to rest
text:
comments Let's put Bret Bielema vs. Cam Robinson to rest Alabama Beat Reporter Show, Oct. 12, 2015 Alabama beat reporters John Talty and Matt Zenitz discuss the twitter report that Arkansas head coach Bret Beilema feigned bump from Alabama offensive lineman Cam Robinson then celebrated the resulting flag. 
Cam Robinson was wrong and has acknowledged as much. 
Bret Bielema was wrong and hasn't taken responsibility for his actions. 
Bielema was right when he said the whole thing has been "blown out of catastrophic proportion." 
Any more questions? 
You'll disagree if you've traded your pig snout for a tinfoil hat this week because an ESPN sound man on the Arkansas sideline waved his hand, but a few things seem perfectly clear after watching different video clips that should not be confused with the Zapruder film. 
And please don't call the whole thing Flop-gate. It's not gate-worthy. 
Alabama's left tackle shouldn't have shoved that Arkansas player after Robinson got knocked to the ground at the end of that interception return in the second quarter of Alabama 27, Arkansas 14 . 
Robinson also shouldn't have raised his hand to Bielema after the Arkansas coach came off the sideline and raised his hand to Robinson. Was able to get another video angle that shows Cam Robinson's personal foul. Doesn't look like a Bret Bielema flop. pic.twitter.com/nCilLLbsWz 
Robinson has admitted the errors of his ways to his head coach, Nick Saban said. Credit to the young man. 
But Bielema shouldn't have come off the sideline and raised his hand to Robinson in the first place. If a coach senses trouble brewing in the heat of the moment, as Bielema said he did, his responsibility as the adult in the room is to help escort his player or players from the scene. 
Instead Bielema confronted Robinson, and it's disappointing that the coach didn't take the same responsibility for his actions that the player did. 
SEC Commissioner Greg Sankey acknowledged Bielema's role in his public statement on the situation . The statement said Sankey spoke to Bielema by phone Monday and advised, "Football is played in an intense competitive environment, and I reminded him of the need for head coaches to resolve with their own players issues that may arise, which was his intent." 
Key phrase: With their own players. Whether it was intended or not, Bielema escalated the incident when he attempted to resolve the issue with Robinson. 
As usual, Sankey chose his words very carefully in his interpretation of "Bret's efforts to intervene at the end of the play." 
Upon further and far too much review by everyone concerned, Sankey handled it just right, and no further intervention on his part was necessary. There was no need to suspend Robinson or Bielema . There was a need to address it and move on. 
Now, with that nuisance off his plate, maybe the commish can get to the bottom of why that ESPN sound guy was waving his hand on the Arkansas sideline, whether he had a camera rolling as well and if he was indeed auditioning for an internship with the New England Patriots. What is going on here? What do these hand signals indicate? Is this guy with ESPN? @SEC @KevinScarbinsky @KTHogs pic.twitter.com/JSrapUjVpD â€” Jim Harris (@jimharris360) October 14, 2015 
Hopefully, Sankey can clear up this confusion before all those black helicopters circling the state of Arkansas run out of gas.
